results.abstract: Soyuz rocket launched from Baikonur, Kazakhstan, lifts Capt William M Shepherd, American who will be international space station's first commander, and Russian astronauts Yuri Gidzenko and Sergei Krikalev into orbit; three men plan to spend four months on station (M)

headline.main: Rocket Lifts 3 Astronauts To the Station Built in Space

results.snippet: One American and two Russian astronauts rocketed into orbit today on a quest to become the first residents of the international space station and begin fulfilling the once-fantastic dream of permanent occupancy in space.    ''Let's go do it!''...
results.lead_paragraph: One American and two Russian astronauts rocketed into orbit today on a quest to become the first residents of the international space station and begin fulfilling the once-fantastic dream of permanent occupancy in space. ''Let's go do it!'' shouted Capt. William M. Shepherd of the United States Navy, the space station's first commander, before climbing into a Soyuz rocket and blasting off from the same pad where the Space Age began 43 years ago with Sputnik.

results.abstract: Bryan Burrough Op-Ed article laments that launching of two Russian and American astronauts as first inhabitants of International Space Station was greeted with 'giant yawn', even though it represents dawn of historic new era in space exploration; says romantic age of space exploration died moment Neil Armstrong stepped onto moon; photo (M)

headline.main: Giant Leap, Tiny Footprint

results.snippet: A historic era in space exploration dawned yesterday, with an American astronaut and two Russian cosmonauts -- the first permanent crew to inhabit the new International Space Station -- blasting into orbit atop a Soyuz rocket launched from the...
results.lead_paragraph: A historic era in space exploration dawned yesterday, with an American astronaut and two Russian cosmonauts -- the first permanent crew to inhabit the new International Space Station -- blasting into orbit atop a Soyuz rocket launched from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Central Asia. Other than their families, science teachers and CNN watchers, no one on Earth seemed to notice.

results.abstract: Steve Allen, versatile entertainer who created the Tonight show for NBC in 1953 and was widely regarded as a founding father of late-night talk show, dies at age 78; photo (M)

headline.main: Steve Allen, Comedian Who Pioneered Late-Night TV Talk Shows, Is Dead at 78

results.snippet: Steve Allen, the versatile entertainer who created the ''Tonight'' show for NBC in 1953 and was widely regarded as a founding father of the late-night talk show, died on Monday at the home of his son Bill in Los Angeles. He was 78 and lived in Los...
results.lead_paragraph: Steve Allen, the versatile entertainer who created the ''Tonight'' show for NBC in 1953 and was widely regarded as a founding father of the late-night talk show, died on Monday at the home of his son Bill in Los Angeles. He was 78 and lived in Los Angeles. The cause was apparently a heart attack, his family said.

results.abstract: Editorial lauds launching of American and two Russian astronauts from Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan to dock with new International Space Station and become its first inhabitants; says more pressing task will be to design high-quality research agenda for $60 billion engineering project lest it remain structure in search of mission (S)

headline.main: Opening the Space Station

results.snippet: There was something anticlimactic about yesterday's launch of an American and two Russians toward the International Space Station, whose first linked modules are now circling 240 miles overhead, ready to be activated and expanded. The huge $60...
results.lead_paragraph: There was something anticlimactic about yesterday's launch of an American and two Russians toward the International Space Station, whose first linked modules are now circling 240 miles overhead, ready to be activated and expanded. The huge $60 billion engineering project has been delayed repeatedly, and when the astronauts were finally sent aloft from the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan, the venture got limited attention in an America absorbed in its closest presidential race in years. Even so, if all goes well in coming years, this could mark the start for Americans of continuous operations in space as opposed to intermittent shuttle trips. This page has been lukewarm about the station from the beginning, feeling that it would be enormously costly and yield only limited scientific returns, most of which could be gained by satellites and unmanned probes to the solar system. Many of the claims advanced for the station -- such as the opportunity it provides to grow perfect crystals in the absence of gravity and to perform other exquisite manufacturing tasks -- have been hyped beyond reason and debunked by expert committees. But that does not mean there is no value at all in the enterprise. The fact that 16 nations are collaborating on the American-led project is a diplomatic achievement, as is the participation of Russian space and rocket scientists who might otherwise be tempted to put their skills to malevolent use. Once the station is fully assembled and running, scientists may learn more about how astronauts react, physically and mentally, to extended periods in space. The astronauts will master the skills for assembling big structures in space.

results.abstract: Men in the News profiles of three astronauts aboard International Space Station: Capt William M Shepherd, 51-year-old Navy man and veteran of three space shuttle flights, Sergei Konstantinovich Krikalev, 42-year-old civilian engineer, and Lt Col Yuri P Gidzenko, 38-year-old astronaut since 1989, who spent six months on Russian space station Mir; photos (M)

headline.main: Men in the News; The Crew of the International Space Station

results.snippet: William McMichael Shepherd      He sees space as a great ocean. Not surprising for an astronaut who is a Navy man, in love with the sea. A veteran of three space shuttle flights, Capt. William M. Shepherd is sailing off on his greatest voyage, as...
results.lead_paragraph: William McMichael Shepherd He sees space as a great ocean. Not surprising for an astronaut who is a Navy man, in love with the sea. A veteran of three space shuttle flights, Capt. William M. Shepherd is sailing off on his greatest voyage, as commander of the first crew to live aboard the International Space Station.

headline.main: SPARE TIMES

results.snippet: ATTRACTIONS    Museums and Sites    ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted to a Victorian cottage in the 19th century, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. ''Ferryboat,''...
results.lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted to a Victorian cottage in the 19th century, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. ''Ferryboat,'' photographs by Charles Martin, through Dec. 31. Hours: Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $2; children 12 and under, free. Information: (718) 816-4506.

results.abstract: Astronauts from United States and Russia arrive at International Space Station and begin what they hope will be continuous habitation of expanding research platform 240 miles above Earth; their visit is scheduled to last four months; to reach this point, project has had to weather large cost overruns, questions about its scientific value, years of delays by financially strapped Russian space agency and delicate negotiating among nations involved; those on board are Russian astronauts, Lt Col Yuri P Gidzenko and Sergei K Krikalev, and American mission commander, Capt William M Shepherd; NASA is leading the project; photos; diagrams (M)

headline.main: A New, and Ambitious, Home Away From Home

results.snippet: Eight years after the United States and Russia agreed to cooperate in a permanent human outpost in space, astronauts from both countries arrived at the International Space Station today and began what they hope will be continuous habitation of an...
results.lead_paragraph: Eight years after the United States and Russia agreed to cooperate in a permanent human outpost in space, astronauts from both countries arrived at the International Space Station today and began what they hope will be continuous habitation of an expanding research platform 240 miles above Earth. A Soyuz spacecraft carrying an American astronaut and two Russians docked at the 80-ton station at 4:21 a.m. Eastern time as the two craft passed over Kazakhstan, site of the crew's launching two days ago.

results.abstract: Roberta Smith reviews re-opening show at International Center of Photography, which has completely remodeled midtown space pending consolidation of its collection; photos (M)

headline.main: In New Galleries, a Collection of the Unexpected

results.snippet: PHOTOGRAPHY is at a peculiar juncture right now. It crowds the walls of museums and commercial galleries with images that pointedly question its powers -- a medium flaunting its disillusionments. Traditional silver-based still images stand by...
results.lead_paragraph: PHOTOGRAPHY is at a peculiar juncture right now. It crowds the walls of museums and commercial galleries with images that pointedly question its powers -- a medium flaunting its disillusionments. Traditional silver-based still images stand by helplessly as digitization and video claim a piece of their territory, a conquest that seems only to heighten interest in both winners and losers. For several years, as this ferment has intensified, the International Center of Photography, New York's only photography museum, has slipped out of the center of attention. Its exhibition program, with some notable exceptions, has been stodgy, and the excitement has landed elsewhere.

results.abstract: Roundup of films set for fall/winter release; photos (M)

headline.main: Escape Routes to Mars, Whoville and Elsewhere

results.snippet: SO much for the end of the year as the season of serious films for grown-ups. As the holidays approach, escapism is running rampant. Moviegoers can find Terence Stamp rocketing to Mars, Christine Baranski hanging out in Whoville and Jeremy Irons...
results.lead_paragraph: SO much for the end of the year as the season of serious films for grown-ups. As the holidays approach, escapism is running rampant. Moviegoers can find Terence Stamp rocketing to Mars, Christine Baranski hanging out in Whoville and Jeremy Irons battling evil in a fantasy empire. Actual distant lands are popular, too, with an unusual number of films from Asia. And most of the children's films are set on other continents. Even close to home, the world seems to be awash in vampires, werewolves, seemingly normal humans with supernatural powers and young people close to the Devil. At least most of the documentaries are serious. And in the midst of it all, there are love stories, war dramas and portraits of artists as violently talented men. Opening dates, as always, are subject to change. November ''SUZHOU RIVER'' From mainland China, a modernist film noir about a videomaker's attraction to two women (played ''Vertigo'' style by the same actress). One is an exotic dancer; the other is a teenager in love with a motorcycle messenger. Lou Ye is the director. Zhou Xun and Jia Hongsheng star. Opens Wednesday. ''ANGEL'S LADIES'' A documentary about Angel and Mack Moore, an Oregon couple who retired to Nevada to run a legal brothel. And are darned proud of it. Directed by Doug Lindeman, who has produced films about the pornographic film industry and lesbian bars. Friday. ''LOOKING FOR AN ECHO'' Where are the doo-wop stars of yesteryear? Armand Assante plays one, now 50, widowed and tending bar in Brooklyn. Then he meets a woman (Diane Venora) and all sorts of feelings, including his love for music, spring back to life. Directed by Martin Davidson (''The Lords of Flatbush''). Friday. ''ME AND ISAAC NEWTON'' The newest documentary from Michael Apted, who did the acclaimed ''Seven-Up'' series of films. Noted scientists talk about their specialties including robots, lemurs and a unified theory of everything. Friday. ''MEN OF HONOR'' The first black Navy SEAL and the racist senior officer who hates him, at first. Cuba Gooding Jr. and Robert De Niro star. Directed by George Tillman Jr., who wrote and directed ''Soul Food.'' Friday. ''NONSTOP'' A comic chase movie featuring a bank robber, a convenience store clerk and a mobster racing through the streets of Tokyo. Written and directed by Sabu (a k a Hiroyuki Tanaka). Friday. ''REBELS WITH A CAUSE'' Remembering S.D.S., the college organization that put the radical politics in the 60's. A documentary by Helen Garvy, who helped found Students for a Democratic Society's Harvard chapter in 1962. Friday. ''RED PLANET'' Val Kilmer does sci-fi. He plays a member of the American astronaut team on the first manned flight to Mars. Everyone's a little stressed, because Earth is on its last legs and a Martian colony is their only hope, so there are a few emotional flare-ups. With Benjamin Bratt, Terence Stamp and Carrie-Anne Moss. Directed by Anthony Hoffman. Friday. ''YOU CAN COUNT ON ME'' She's a respectable churchgoing single mom. He's an irresponsible drifter. They're sister and brother, reunited in their childhood home and having unexpected effects on each other. Their story, starring Laura Linney and Mark Ruffalo, won two major prizes at this year's Sundance Film Festival. Written and directed by the playwright Kenneth Lonergan. Friday. ''BOUNCE'' Gwyneth Paltrow and Ben Affleck together again. He's a hip L.A. ad man who gives away his airline seat on a flight that crashes, then falls in love with the widow of the man who took his place. Shades of Harrison Ford and Kristin Scott Thomas's ''Random Hearts.'' This one is written and directed by Don Roos, who did the terrific ''Opposite of Sex.'' Nov. 17. ''DR. SEUSS' HOW THE GRINCH STOLE CHRISTMAS'' If you're going to bring the grouchy green Grinch to life, Jim Carrey is probably your best bet, even if he's unrecognizable in fur. The Grinch, as every child knows, is determined to keep the residents of Whoville from celebrating their favorite holiday. Ron Howard directed. Christine Baranski, Molly Shannon and Bill Irwin play Whos. Nov. 17. A related article is on Page 9. ''LA BUCHE'' Three sisters in Paris deal with multiple romantic problems during Christmas week (unplanned pregnancy, straying husband, married lover, handsome young handyman with a secret). Emmanuelle Beart, Charlotte Gainsbourg and Sabine Azema star. Directed by Daniele Thompson. Nov. 17. Related articles are on Page 3. ''LIES'' Sadomasochism in South Korea. A teenage virgin and a much older sculptor meet, get kinky and turn into sex addicts. Jang Sun Woo is the director. Nov. 17. ''LITTLE NICKY'' Adam Sandler as the Devil's son, who's forced to move from hell to New York and finds the transition tough. His job: find his two no-good brothers and restore the balance of good and evil in the world. Harvey Keitel plays Satan. Directed by Steve Brill, who wrote the ''Mighty Ducks'' movies. Nov. 17. ''ONE DAY IN SEPTEMBER'' Last year's Oscar winner for documentary feature, shown on HBO earlier this year, goes back to theaters. It's the story of the terrorist murders of Olympic athletes at the 1972 Summer Games in Munich. Directed by Kevin Macdonald. Nov. 17. ''RUGRATS IN PARIS -- THE MOVIE'' The little Pickleses and Finsters go abroad, presumably with their parents. The second movie based on the Nickelodeon series ''Rugrats,'' and the first was a joy. Nov. 17. ''SASAYAKI (MOONLIGHT WHISPERS)'' A high school romance about sexual degradation. The filmmakers compare it to an ''After School Special'' directed by Luis Bunuel. Actually directed (and written) by Akihiko Shiota. Nov. 17. ''THE SIXTH DAY'' Arnold Schwarzenegger in a futuristic thriller. He's been cloned and his wife (Wendy Crewson) can't tell the difference. He also makes an enemy of a ruthless gazillionaire (Tony Goldwyn) and his scientist partner (Robert Duvall). Directed by Roger Spottiswoode. Nov. 17. ''WHAT'S COOKING?'' Thanksgiving in Los Angeles with four families (black, Latino, Jewish and Vietnamese). The ensemble cast includes Alfre Woodard, Joan Chen, Mercedes Ruehl and Dennis Haysbert. Directed by Gurinder Chadha. Nov. 17. ''THE WOLVES OF KROMER'' A British mystery about gay werewolves. Two handsome young wolves (James Layton and Lee Williams) are framed for murder, and the whole village (including the local priest, who's a little wolfish himself) turns against them. It's a mix of love story, black comedy and folk tale. Will Gould, 22, is the director. Boy George, 39, narrates. Nov. 17. ''MALENA'' Think ''Summer of '42'' in Sicily with laughs. Giuseppe Tornatore, who made ''Cinema Paradiso,'' is the director. Monica Bellucci, who played Gene Hackman's wife in ''Under Suspicion,'' is the World War II widow adored by a group of Sicilian boys busy coming of age. Nov. 22. ''102 DALMATIANS'' Cruella De Vil goes to Paris. Glenn Close, back as Cruella in this live-action Disney sequel, is joined by Gerard Depardieu (as a dastardly French furrier) and scores of cute spotted dogs. Maybe they'll run into the Rugrats. Directed by Kevin Lima. Nov. 22. A related article is on Page 9. ''QUILLS'' The Marquis de Sade's twilight years. Geoffrey Rush plays the world's most sexually notorious noble, writing away in Charenton Asylum. Kate Winslet is the laundry worker who smuggles his erotica out. Michael Caine is the doctor who wants to cure him of this nasty habit. Directed by Philip Kaufman, who did ''The Right Stuff'' and ''Henry and June.'' Nov. 22. A related article is on Page 3. ''THE TRENCH'' The bloody Battle of the Somme, 1916. Directed by the novelist William Boyd. With Paul Nicholls and Daniel Craig. Nov. 22. ''TWO NINAS'' Amanda Peet, Cara Buono and Ron Livingston in a love story about two gorgeous women in love with the same man. Written and directed by Neil Turitz. Nov. 22. ''UNBREAKABLE'' It's the ''Sixth Sense'' team again (minus Haley Joel Osment). M. Night Shyamalan directs Bruce Willis as a man who miraculously survives a terrible train crash. (One has to ask immediately: Or does he?) Samuel L. Jackson plays a man with an explanation for it. Nov. 22. ''THE WEEKEND'' Gena Rowlands, Jared Harris, Deborah Kara Unger, Brooke Shields and others at a country house to commemorate the anniversary of the death of a man they all cared about. Brian Skeet wrote and directed. Nov. 22. December ''A GOOD BABY'' One critic called it ''Flannery O'Connor meets Krzysztof Kieslowski.'' Henry Thomas plays a reclusive young North Carolina man who finds an abandoned baby in the woods and goes searching for its mother. Directed by Katherine Dieckmann, making her feature film debut. Dec. 1. ''SPRING FORWARD'' A year in the workday partnership of a young ex-con (Liev Schreiber) and an imminent parks department retiree (Ned Beatty). It's a sensitive guy thing, written and directed by Tom Gilroy. Dec. 1. ''TERROR FIRMER'' From Troma Entertainment, which regularly sinks to new levels of weird bad taste (see ''Tromeo and Juliet,'' for starters), the story of a film crew, a blind director (played by the film's director, Lloyd Kaufman) and a sexually confused serial killer. Dec. 1. ''FINDING FORRESTER'' A male mentor picture from Gus Van Sant. Sean Connery is a reclusive novelist; Rob Brown, a newcomer, is a young basketball star who, it turns out, is also a brilliant writer. Is that the theme music to ''Good Will Hunting'' we hear? With Busta Rhymes, F. Murray Abraham, Anna Paquin and, as a Yankee stadium guard, Joey Buttafuoco. Dec. 6. ''HILLBROW KIDS'' Street children in South Africa, begging, getting high and trying to stay alive. Jacqueline Gorgen and Michael Hammon directed this documentary, named for a tough Johannesburg neighborhood. Dec. 6. ''THE ART OF AMALIA'' A documentary tribute to the hugely popular Portuguese fado singer Amalia Rodrigues, who died last year. This is Bruno de Almeida's fourth film about her. Dec. 8. ''BOYS LIFE 3'' Five short films about gay life, including ''Majorettes in Space.'' There's star power this time: Sara Gilbert as star and director of ''$30'' and Jason Gould as star and director of ''Inside Out,'' which also features his father, Elliot Gould, and Christina Crawford. Dec. 8. ''CROUCHING TIGER, HIDDEN DRAGON'' After ''The Ice Storm'' and ''Sense and Sensibility,'' Ang Lee looks homeward. Chow Yun Fat and Michelle Yeoh star in this martial arts film set in ancient China. A love story too, it was a huge hit at the Cannes International Film Festival. Dec. 8. A related article is on Page 25. ''THE DAY SILENCE DIED'' Magic realism in Bolivia. A small, isolated town gets its first radio and everybody overreacts. Directed by Paolo Agazzi. Dec. 8. ''DUNGEONS AND DRAGONS'' Jeremy Irons and Thora Birch in a fantasy adventure about a young empress, an evil magician, magic rods and scepters, deadly mazes and secret grottoes. It's based on one generation's favorite game and goes heavy on the visual effects. Courtney Solomon is the first-time director. Dec. 8. ''PROOF OF LIFE'' Russell Crowe and Meg Ryan star as a hostage negotiator and a hostage's wife who fall in love. (Yes, this is where the stars' own romance began.) David Morse plays Ms. Ryan's husband. The film, set in South America, is directed by Taylor Hackford. Dec. 8. ''VERTICAL LIMIT'' Chris O'Donnell in an action-adventure story about a traumatized ex-mountaineer who may have to take up climbing again to save his sister (Robin Tunney), who is trapped 26,000 feet up. Originally scheduled for release last summer. Directed by Martin Campbell. Dec. 8. ''CHOCOLAT'' From Lasse Hallstrom, whose work includes ''My Life as a Dog'' to ''The Cider House Rules.'' Juliette Binoche plays a single mother who moves to a prudish French village and scandalizes everyone by opening a chocolaterie with sinfully good merchandise. Johnny Depp plays another outsider, Alfred Molina the head prude. Dec. 15. ''DUDE, WHERE'S MY CAR?'' Party-loving young men forget where they parked. A comedy about losing your girlfriend's anniversary present. With Ashton Kutcher of ''That 70's Show.'' Directed by Danny Leiner. Dec. 15. ''THE EMPEROR'S NEW GROOVE'' Disney's animated extravaganza of the season, a buddy movie set in South America. It seems a selfish young emperor is turned into a llama by a disgruntled ex-employee. But when he teams up with a humble llama herder, he becomes a much nicer human being. With the voices of David Spade, Eartha Kitt and John Goodman. Directed by Mark Dindal. Music by Sting. Dec. 15. ''FAMILY MAN'' A romantic comedy for Christmas. Imagine George Bailey in ''It's a Wonderful Life'' as a fast-lane bachelor investment banker. That's Jack Campbell (Nicolas Cage), who wakes up one December morning to find himself married with children and a minivan. Tea Leoni is his wife in this alternative existence. Brett Ratner, who did ''Rush Hour,'' directed. Dec. 15. A related article is on Page 3. ''POLLOCK'' Ed Harris directs himself as Jackson Pollock, Abstract Expressionist genius, midcentury American celebrity and self-hating alcoholic. Marcia Gay Harden plays the artist Lee Krasner, his wife. Val Kilmer turns up as Willem de Kooning. This biography was the New York Film Festival's official centerpiece, and highly praised. December 15. ''WHAT WOMEN WANT'' Mel Gibson as an ad executive who suddenly develops the ability to read women's minds. He promptly takes advantage. With Helen Hunt, Marisa Tomei and Lauren Holly. Nancy Meyers, who did ''The Parent Trap'' (and was a co-writer on ''Private Benjamin'' and ''Baby Boom''), directed. Dec. 15. ''BUT FOREVER IN MY MIND'' An Italian comedy about teenage hormones, male bonding and the shadow of the 1960's student protests. Silvio Muccino stars, Gabriele Muccino directed, and the two wrote the script together. Dec. 20. ''THIRTEEN DAYS'' Kevin Costner plays a presidential aide in a behind-the-scenes drama about the 1962 Cuban missile crisis. Bruce Greenwood plays J. F. K. Roger Donaldson directed. Dec. 20. A related article is on Page 19. ''BEFORE NIGHT FALLS''' The artist Julian Schnabel tries film directing again (he did ''Basquiat''), this time with a biography of Reinaldo Arenas, the exiled Cuban poet and novelist. Javier Bardem plays Arenas, who committed suicide (he had AIDS) in 1990. Johnny Depp also stars. The film was very well received at the New York Film Festival this year. Dec. 22. A related article is on Page 44. ''CAST AWAY'' Tom Hanks in Robinson Crusoe mode (and weight). He's a stressed-out FedEx worker now trying to survive alone on a desert island after his plane crashes. Helen Hunt is the woman he left behind. Directed by Robert Zemeckis, whose last film with Mr. Hanks (''Forrest Gump'') turned out pretty well. Dec. 22. A related article is on Page 1. ''THE GIFT'' Cate Blanchett, Hilary Swank, Keanu Reeves and Greg Kinnear in a Southern Gothic thriller written by Billy Bob Thornton and Tim Epperson. Ms. Blanchett is a small-town Georgia widow with psychic powers. But like all movie towns, this one has secrets and she sees a little too much. Sam Raimi directed. Dec. 22. ''THE HOUSE OF MIRTH'' Edith Wharton's 1905 New York, rich with cruelty, hypocrisy and greed -- and one woman's descent from its upper class. Gillian Anderson stars as Lily Bart, with Eric Stoltz, Dan Aykroyd, Anthony La Paglia and Terry Kinney as the men of varying intentions around her. Terence Davies wrote and directed. Dec. 22. ''MISS CONGENIALITY'' Sandra Bullock plays an F.B.I. agent posing as a Miss New Jersey contestant in order to prevent a bombing. It's a comedy. Benjamin Bratt, Michael Caine and William Shatner are her co-stars. Directed by Donald Petrie, who did ''Grumpy Old Men.'' Dec. 22. ''NOWHERE TO HIDE'' A Korean detective looking for a murderer. Directed by Lee Myung-Se. Dec. 22. ''O BROTHER, WHERE ART THOU?'' Loved him in the E.R. Loved him tossed at sea. Now will we love George Clooney on the road in rural Mississippi? He plays an escaped convict in Joel and Ethan Coen's tribute to Preston Sturges's 1941 film ''Sullivan's Travels,'' a sort of Depression-era ''Odyssey.'' They liked it a lot at the Cannes International Film Festival. With John Turturro and Tim Blake Nelson. Dec. 22. A related article is on Page 29. ''STATE AND MAIN'' David Mamet makes fun of movie people. Alec Baldwin, Philip Seymour Hoffman, William H. Macy and Sarah Jessica Parker star as part of a film cast and crew who invade a quiet Vermont town, armed with cell phones and portable egos. Julia Stiles plays a local teenager who gets close to one of them. Dec. 22. ''WES CRAVEN PRESENTS: DRACULA 2000'' What if Count Dracula were around today, surrounded by all those young Goths in America? He is. Gerard Butler and Jonny Lee Miller star, and Christopher Plummer plays Van Helsing. Mr. Craven is an executive producer; Patrick Lussier, who worked with him on ''Scream 2'' and ''Scream 3,'' directed. Dec. 22. ''ALL THE PRETTY HORSES'' Matt Damon and Henry Thomas as Texas teenagers who head for Mexico to be cowboys. We've been waiting more than a year now for this one, based on Cormac McCarthy's award-winning western novel, set in the 1940's. With Penlope Cruz. Billy Bob Thornton directed. Dec. 25. ''AN EVERLASTING PIECE'' Barry Levinson gets out of Baltimore -- to do a comedy about barbers in Belfast. It's the story of a Protestant and a Roman Catholic who become highly unlikely partners in a toupee business in Northern Ireland. Barry McEvoy and Brian F. O'Byrne are the stars. Dec. 25. ''VATEL'' A 17th-century costume drama with a Tom Stoppard script (written with Jeanne LaBrune). Gerard Depardieu stars as Louis XIV's caterer, in love with the king's favorite courtesan (Uma Thurman). Roland Joffe directed. Dec. 25. ''TRAFFIC'' The latest from Steven Soderbergh (''Sex, Lies and Videotape,'' ''Erin Brockovich''), a thriller about the drug trade. Michael Douglas stars as anti-drug czar designate; Catherine Zeta-Jones is a drug lord's wife who runs the business. Don Cheadle plays a narc. Dec. 27. ''CHUNHYANG'' An operatic love story set in 18th-century Korea. The governor's son and the courtesan's daughter love each other, and that means trouble. Directed by Im Kwon Taek, who interweaves pansori, a stylized musical-narrative . Cho Seung Woo and Lee Hyo Jung star. Dec. 29. A related article is on Page 25. ''THE CLAIM'' Thomas Hardy's novel ''The Mayor of Casterbridge'' with the names and location changed. But it's still about a poor man who sells his wife and his daughter for a not-so-proverbial pot of gold, then suffers when they come back to haunt him 20 years later. He just happens to be rich and successful now. Peter Mullan, Nastassja Kinski, Milla Jovovich, Sarah Polley and Wes Bentley star. Michael Winterbottom (''Wonderland'') directed. Dec. 29. ''SHADOW OF THE VAMPIRE'' The year is 1922, and the pioneering German director F. W. Murnau (John Malkovich) is making his silent horror classic ''Nosferatu.'' Willem Dafoe plays the film's star, Max Schreck, who appears to be a real vampire. This is not good news for cast and crew. E. Elias Merhige, a first-timer, directed. Dec. 29. A related article is on Page 3. ''SIMON MAGUS'' Noah Taylor (he was the young David Helfgott in ''Shine'') plays a 19th-century boy whose fellow villagers believe he's possessed by the Devil. It's a horror fantasy romance that revolves around plans for a railway station, directed by Ben Hopkins, a first-timer. With Ian Holm as the Devil. Dec. 29. ''THE VISIT'' A prison drama starring Hill Harper (Dr. Wesley Williams on CBS's ''City of Angels''). Mr. Harper plays a terminally ill young man whose family rarely turns up on visitors' day. Billy Dee Williams and Marla Gibbs portray his parents and Obba Babatunde his successful-businessman brother. Jordan Walker-Pearlman wrote and directed. December. January ''NIGHT WALTZ: THE MUSIC OF PAUL BOWLES'' Owsley Brown's documentary about Bowles, the expatriate author who died a year ago this month, and his lesser-known career as a composer. Jan. 3. ''THE PERSONALS'' From China, a comedy about a young woman who places an ad to find a husband. Directed by Chen Kuo-Fu. Jan. 5. ''TERRORISTS IN RETIREMENT'' Simone Signoret narrated this 1984 documentary a year before she died. It's the story of Jewish immigrants in Nazi-occupied Paris, taking the most dangerous assignments in the Resistance. The surviving fighters, elderly men now, are interviewed, and what they say doesn't always reflect well on the official Resistance. Maybe that's why it was originally banned from French television. Directed by Mosco Boucault. Jan. 10. ''ANTITRUST'' Dark doings in the computer industry. Ryan Phillippe plays the eager young software designer. Tim Robbins, the company's billionaire founder, is his mentor. Peter Howitt (''Sliding Doors'') directed. Jan. 12. ''THE PLEDGE'' That old story about a cop nanoseconds away from retirement who becomes involved in something big, in this case an 8-year-old girl's murder. But it could be nice to see Jack Nicholson in ''Chinatown'' mode again. And he has an amazing supporting cast, including Vanessa Redgrave, Sam Shepard and Helen Mirren. The uncompromising Sean Penn directed. Jan. 12. ''SAVE THE LAST DANCE'' Hip-hop versus ballet in a musical drama directed by Thomas Carter. With Julia Stiles and Sean Patrick Thomas. Jan. 12. Compiled with the assistance of Suzanne O'Connor.

results.abstract: Article on Tom Hanks' new film, Cast Away, directed by Robert Zemeckis, conceived by Hanks and written by William Broyles Jr; photos (M)

headline.main: Marooned On an Island, Out on a Limb

results.snippet: EARLY last month, Tom Hanks could be found in a Four Seasons Hotel banquet hall in Beverly Hills, seated between his wife, Rita Wilson, and Holly Hunter. On his plate, there wasn't much left of his mesclun greens and goat cheese salad. But judging...
results.lead_paragraph: EARLY last month, Tom Hanks could be found in a Four Seasons Hotel banquet hall in Beverly Hills, seated between his wife, Rita Wilson, and Holly Hunter. On his plate, there wasn't much left of his mesclun greens and goat cheese salad. But judging from how much he was laughing, Mr. Hanks was enjoying more than just his meal. He was there to present Ms. Hunter, an old friend, with a special career achievement award at Premiere magazine's ''Women in Hollywood'' luncheon, an annual event known for its high giddiness factor. So while Mr. Hanks heaped praise on Ms. Hunter, he also laced his podium time with teasing ad-libs and did a clipped, weirdly high-pitched imitation of Ms. Hunter's husband, the Polish cinematographer Janusz Kaminski.

results.abstract: Harvard University has launched wide recruitment drive for candidate to replace departing president, Neil L Rudenstine, and has already received approximately 500 nominations; anyone and everyone is invited to send in thoughts and suggestions; selection committee has no students, no faculty members and no desire to advertise its deliberations before it reaches conclusion; photo (M)

headline.main: Wanted: One President For Famous University

results.snippet: Could there possibly be a more delicious nugget to drop into conversation at the faculty club than this? ''Oh, by the way, I'm told I've been nominated for the presidency of Harvard.''     For hundreds of deans, department heads and miscellaneous...
results.lead_paragraph: Could there possibly be a more delicious nugget to drop into conversation at the faculty club than this? ''Oh, by the way, I'm told I've been nominated for the presidency of Harvard.'' For hundreds of deans, department heads and miscellaneous leading figures around the country, just such an ego-feeding delicacy is legitimately theirs these days. Harvard University is seeking to replace its departing president, Neil L. Rudenstine, by next summer, and the net it is casting is so wide -- and, at this early stage, so uncharacteristically undiscriminating -- that it has received about 500 nominations. (Not so many, really, considering that it sent more than 300,000 letters asking for suggestions.)

headline.main: SOUTH

results.snippet: FLORIDA         RECOUNT      In the race that defied imagination and will determine who is the next president, Florida officials began a two-day recount yesterday of six million votes to determine who won this state, with its 25 electoral votes.

byline.original: This report was written by Elizabeth Becker, John H. Cushman Jr., Nichole M. Christian, Abby Goodnough, Laura Mansnerus, Todd S. Purdum, Diana Jean Schemo, Jacques Steinberg, Matthew L. Wald, Amy Waldman and Kate Zernike

results.lead_paragraph: FLORIDA RECOUNT In the race that defied imagination and will determine who is the next president, Florida officials began a two-day recount yesterday of six million votes to determine who won this state, with its 25 electoral votes.

headline.main: SPARE TIMES

results.snippet: ATTRACTIONS    Museums and Sites    AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. Costumes, set pieces, film equipment and other items relating to film, television and video are on permanent display....
results.lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. Costumes, set pieces, film equipment and other items relating to film, television and video are on permanent display. ''Visions of New York: Films From the 1960's Underground,'' including guest appearances by filmmakers; through Dec. 3. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., Warren Finnerty's ''Connection'' (1961); at 4 p.m., Dick Higgins's ''Flaming City'' (1963). Sunday at 2 p.m., ''The Underground Above Ground: New York Institutions and the Avant-Garde,'' a panel discussion with P. Adams Sitney, Lawrence Kardish and Amos Voge; at 4 p.m., Mr. Kardish's ''Low Run'' (1968). Repertory nights: tomorrow and Sunday at 6:30 p.m., Brian De Palma's ''Greetings'' (1968). All activities are free with museum admission unless otherwise indicated. Admission: $8.50; the elderly and students, $5.50; ages 5 to 18, $4.50; 4 and under, free. Information: (718) 784-0077.

results.abstract: Ken Johnson reviews exhibit of mroe than 200 toy robots and space toys, at Brooklyn Museum; photo of Buck Rogers rocket ship from 1934 (M)

headline.main: Artifacts of Pop Past: Toys for That Inner Child Who Dotes on Buck Rogers

results.snippet: Connoisseurs of kitsch, semioticians and youngsters of all ages should get a kick out of the Brooklyn Museum of Art's ''Robots and Space Toys: The Robert Lesser Collection.'' Entertaining and unexpectedly thought-provoking, the exhibition presents...
results.lead_paragraph: Connoisseurs of kitsch, semioticians and youngsters of all ages should get a kick out of the Brooklyn Museum of Art's ''Robots and Space Toys: The Robert Lesser Collection.'' Entertaining and unexpectedly thought-provoking, the exhibition presents more than 200 toy robots, rocket ships, flying saucers, astronauts and space stations produced mostly by Japanese manufacturers for the American market after World War II. Devoted mainly to robots, the collection is said to be one of the largest of its kind in the world. It was assembled by Robert Lesser, a Manhattan resident, over the last two decades. A few people might ask, however, why is this sort of low-end commercial juvenilia being showcased at a museum of fine art? One answer is that it belongs to the history of modern design. Displayed in vitrines like ancient artifacts or crowded onto shelves in bright red and yellow wall cases like merchandise in a toy store, the objects on view do relate to 20th-century design in general as they evolve through a series of stylistic periods: the Machine Age, the Atomic Age, the Space Age and the Age of Real Space Exploration. At that point, in the early 1970's, children's interests shifted elsewhere, and the robot and space toy industry collapsed.

results.abstract: Sampling of educational software on market; photos (M)

headline.main: Software for the School Zone, but Watch Your Speed

results.snippet: EDUCATIONAL software is suffering from what for lack of a better term might be called megahertz creep. That is the tendency for late-model programs to require ever-faster processor speeds to function properly.     Gone are the days when most programs...
results.lead_paragraph: EDUCATIONAL software is suffering from what for lack of a better term might be called megahertz creep. That is the tendency for late-model programs to require ever-faster processor speeds to function properly. Gone are the days when most programs for personal computers would run on anything from a 486 chip on up. This year, many new titles require a PC with a Pentium chip, usually starting at 133 megahertz or higher. Most Macintosh software requires a PowerPC chip or better.

headline.main: SPARE TIMES

results.snippet: ATTRACTIONS    Museums and Sites    ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted to a Victorian cottage in the 19th century, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. ''Ferryboat,''...
results.lead_paragraph: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted to a Victorian cottage in the 19th century, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. ''Ferryboat,'' photographs by Charles Martin, through Dec. 31. Tomorrow from 10 to 11:30 a.m., ''The Christmas Stocking,'' stories, crafts and refreshments. For youngsters 9 to 12. Reservations required. Admission: $10; $8 for members. Hours: Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $2; children 12 and under, free. Information: (718) 816-4506.

results.abstract: Lawyers for Dr Robert Bierenbaum, who was convicted of murdering his wife and dumping her body from plane, ask New York Supreme Court Justice Leslie Crocker Snyder for minimum sentence of 15 years to life, citing his charitable work and community service (M)

headline.main: Minimum Sentence Sought For Doctor Who Killed Wife

results.snippet: Lawyers for a plastic surgeon who was convicted of murdering his wife and dumping her body from a plane have asked a judge for the minimum sentence of 15 years to life.    Citing their client's charity and compassion -- and a recent attack in jail in...
results.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for a plastic surgeon who was convicted of murdering his wife and dumping her body from a plane have asked a judge for the minimum sentence of 15 years to life. Citing their client's charity and compassion -- and a recent attack in jail in which he was bitten by a fellow inmate -- the lawyers also requested protective custody for the surgeon, Dr. Robert Bierenbaum.

results.abstract: Profile of The Outpost Tavern in Webster, Texas, watering hole favored by astronauts, engineers and other workers at nearby Johnson Space Center; tavern, threatened with closing because of its dilapidated state, was rescued from closing with support from NASA veterans like Larry Keyser; photos (L)

headline.main: A Hangout That Caters To a Crowd From Space

results.snippet: For anyone unmoved by sentiment, the Outpost Tavern might not seem worth saving. The old red building is practically falling down. A tangle of bushes growing up an outside wall seems ready to swallow the place. Outside, there is a faint smell of...
results.lead_paragraph: For anyone unmoved by sentiment, the Outpost Tavern might not seem worth saving. The old red building is practically falling down. A tangle of bushes growing up an outside wall seems ready to swallow the place. Outside, there is a faint smell of sewage. But push inside through the swinging doors shaped like two bikini-clad women and sentiment clearly rules the day. Every neighborhood bar has regulars, but the Outpost's neighborhood is NASA and the nearby Johnson Space Center. The walls are lined with photographs of smiling, blue-suited astronauts, not sports stars. Many of the people who come to nurse beers and trade gossip are the engineers, technicians and private contractors who help send people into space. Astronauts drop by, too.

results.abstract: Exhibition of robots and space toys of 1950's and 1960's from collection of Robert Lesser is on view at Brooklyn Museum of Art; photos (M)

headline.main: Friendly Aliens Invade Galleries

results.snippet: BUG-EYED and colorfully dressed like atomic-age samurai, Japanese tin toy robots mesmerized American children in the 1950's and 60's. The robots moved like tanks, beaming light, breathing fire and wobbling to a halt as their batteries died.    When...
results.lead_paragraph: BUG-EYED and colorfully dressed like atomic-age samurai, Japanese tin toy robots mesmerized American children in the 1950's and 60's. The robots moved like tanks, beaming light, breathing fire and wobbling to a halt as their batteries died. When the robots were new, they were made from recycled tin cans left in Japan by G.I.'s during the American occupation. Children fantasized that these warrior machines were destined to conquer Earth and outer space, but not with guns for the most part. Instead they were armed with what seemed like the latest in electronic gadgetry -- radio antennas, telephones, cameras and television sets -- and as such they were harbingers of the technology revolution. These pop-culture toys helped sell Japanese electronics to the world.

results.abstract: Profile of Erin Lashnits, senior at Horace Greeley High School in Chappaqua who closed out her high-school diving career last weekend by moving up to 7th place on her final dives in state championships in Buffalo, NY; Lashnits comments; photos (M)

headline.main: A Diver Since 9, Erin Lashnits Reaches Higher

results.snippet: ERIN LASHNITS has spent much of her life looking down from a few meters off the ground. She has been diving since she was 9.    But someday she hopes to have a much grander perspective.
results.lead_paragraph: ERIN LASHNITS has spent much of her life looking down from a few meters off the ground. She has been diving since she was 9. But someday she hopes to have a much grander perspective.

results.abstract: Effort is under way to use space shuttle to develop drug to treat Chagas disease, parasitic illness that kills about 45,000 people a year, mostly in Latin America; drugs made through crystallization can be made more uniformly in microgravity of space; Dr Franklin Chang-Diaz, astronaut and physicist, and Dr Lawrence J DeLucas, biochemistry professor on leave to NASA, began string of Chagas experiments on space shuttle in 1996; photo (M)

headline.main: From Jungle to Space in Pursuit of New Drugs

results.snippet: Dr. Franklin Chang-Diaz, a NASA astronaut with roots in Costa Rica, and Dr. Jose Zaglul, president of a university that specializes in agricultural courses for the humid tropics,  were driving onto Dr. Zaglul's campus in Mercedes, Costa Rica, one day...
results.lead_paragraph: Dr. Franklin Chang-Diaz, a NASA astronaut with roots in Costa Rica, and Dr. Jose Zaglul, president of a university that specializes in agricultural courses for the humid tropics, were driving onto Dr. Zaglul's campus in Mercedes, Costa Rica, one day in 1991 when they had a short conversation that has turned into a big idea. Dr. Chang-Diaz, who was in Costa Rica to foster greater Latin American participation in space projects, had just met some Chilean scientists who were trying to cure Chagas' disease, a parasitic illness that kills about 45,000 people a year, mostly in Latin America. As leader of Earth University, or Escuela de Agricultura de la Region Tropical Humeda, Dr. Zaglul was passionate about teaching the importance of biodiversity and sustainable development of natural resources.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Endeavour will lift off from Cape Canaveral on November 30 with five-man crew to add powerful new solar wings to international space station; crew will be first visitors to three astronauts who established long-term residence at station almost month ago; 17-ton package is largest and most complex payload ever transported by shuttle (M)

headline.main: Shuttle to Lift Off Tonight for Space Station

results.snippet: The space shuttle Endeavour is to lift off Thursday night on a mission to add powerful new solar-power wings to the international space station.    The five-man shuttle crew will be the first visitors to the three astronauts who established long-term...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Endeavour is to lift off Thursday night on a mission to add powerful new solar-power wings to the international space station. The five-man shuttle crew will be the first visitors to the three astronauts who established long-term residence at the station almost a month ago.
